title: Question 36

children: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of abdominal discomfort, nausea and vomiting, and pruritus. She is pregnant at 36 weeks' gestation.
On physical examination, temperature is 36.9 °C (98.4 °F), blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg, pulse rate is 98/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. Scleral icterus is noted. She has a gravid uterus.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
The HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets) syndrome typically presents with nonspecific symptoms, such as abdominal pain, nausea with vomiting, pruritus, and jaundice.
The HELLP syndrome is treated by prompt delivery of the fetus.
The most appropriate management is delivery of the fetus (

). The third trimester of pregnancy can be complicated by potentially serious liver conditions. The HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets) syndrome is a serious manifestation of preeclampsia and must be recognized promptly. HELLP typically presents with nonspecific symptoms, such as abdominal pain, nausea with vomiting, pruritus, and jaundice. The only definitive therapy is delivery of the fetus. Prompt treatment is paramount because rates of fetal and maternal mortality are high. Treatment with first-line agents for severe hypertension should occur as soon as possible to reduce the risk for maternal stroke. The goal is to rapidly achieve a blood pressure in the range of 140 to 150/90 to 100 mm Hg. Coagulopathy may increase the risk for bleeding in the perinatal state. Liver dysfunction can worsen in the 48 hours after delivery before resolving. Rarely, liver transplantation may be required if symptoms of liver failure progress.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic (TTP) is characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. Acquired TTP is caused by a deficiency in the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which is responsible for cleaving high-molecular-weight von Willebrand factor multimers. These multimers accumulate, generating platelet-rich thrombi in small vessels. Initial treatment involves therapeutic plasma exchange (

) to remove the multimers and replace the deficient ADAMTS13. Although this patient has hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, a third-trimester pregnancy and elevated liver enzyme levels are more compatible with HELLP syndrome.
If bleeding is not controlled, or if an invasive procedure is planned, transfusion of platelets (
) or plasma may be warranted. In the absence of bleeding, as in this patient, administration of platelets is not necessary. Any intervention that delays delivery of the fetus should be avoided.

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy can develop during earlier stages of pregnancy and causes pruritus. Potential complications include premature labor and fetal death. Although ursodeoxycholic acid (
) can be helpful in intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy, it has no benefit in the HELLP syndrome and therefore is not an appropriate choice for this patient.

objective.__html: Treat the HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets) syndrome.

references: Chandrasekaran S, Simon R. Hepatic complications in preeclampsia. Clin Obstet Gynecol. 2020;63:165-174.
